''See also:'' [[1973 in politics]], [[1974|other events of 1974]], [[1975 in politics]], [[list of years in politics]].
==Events== *January 2 - [[Richard Nixon]] signs a bill lowering the maximum [[United States|U.S.]] [[speed limit]] to 55 MPH in order to conserve [[gasoline]] during an [[OPEC]] embargo. * January 4 - U.S. President [[Richard Nixon]] refuses to hand over materials subpoenaed by the Senate [[Watergate scandal|Watergate]] Committee. * 22 February – [[Pakistan]] recognizes [[Bangladesh]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Bangladesh.html|title=Bangladesh|publisher=World Statesmen|language=English|accessdate=22 September 2012}}</ref> * February 28 - After seven years, the [[United States]] and [[Egypt]] re-establish diplomatic relations. * February 28 - General election in the [[United Kingdom|U.K.]] results in no majority for any party; Labour will form a minority government until October despite having received fewer votes nationally than the Conservatives. See [[United Kingdom general election, February 1974]]. *4 March - [[Harold Wilson]] replaces [[Edward Heath]] as [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] of the [[United Kingdom|UK]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldstatesmen.org/United_Kingdom.html|title=United Kingdom|publisher=World Statesmen|language=English|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref> * March 1 - [[Watergate scandal]]: Seven are indicted for their role in the Watergate break-in and charged with conspiracy to obstruct justice. * April 25 - [[Portugal|Portuguese]] democratic revolution. * May 18 - "[[Smiling Buddha]]" [[nuclear weapon]] test by [[India]]. *29 June - [[Isabel Perón]] replaces [[Juan Perón]] as [[President of Argentina|President]] of [[Argentina]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Argentina.html|title=Argentina|publisher=World Statesmen|language=English|accessdate=23 November 2012}}</ref> * July 20 - [[Turkey]] invades the country of [[Cyprus]] and occupies the northern third of the island (later declared the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus). * August 9 - President [[Richard Nixon]] of the USA resigns, and is replaced with [[Gerald Ford]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldstatesmen.org/United_States.html|title=United States of America|publisher=World Statesmen|language=English|accessdate=2 August 2015}}</ref> *1 September - Acting [[Hugh Watt]] replaces deceased [[Norman Kirk]] as [[Prime Minister of New Zealand|Prime Minister]] of [[New Zealand]].<ref name="New Zealand">{{cite web|url=http://www.worldstatesmen.org/New_Zealand.htm|title=New Zealand|publisher=World Statesmen|language=English|accessdate=1 August 2015}}</ref> *6 September - [[Bill Rowling]] replaces acting [[Hugh Watt]] as Prime Minister of New Zealand.<ref name="New Zealand"/> * September 12 - [[Ethiopia]]n [[Emperor]] [[Haile Selassie]] ousted in a coup by the [[Derg]]. * October 10 - General election in the UK is won narrowly by [[The Labour Party (UK)|Labour]]. See [[United Kingdom general election, October 1974]].

Senior Generalitat figures were officially dismissed from office on 28 October 2017 after direct rule was enforced.}} }} The '''2017–18 Spanish constitutional crisis''',{{cite news |last=Gilbert |first=Mark |date=7 September 2017 |title=Catalonia Cries "Freedom!" Market Says "Not So Fast..." |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-09-07/catalonia-cries-freedom-market-says-not-so-fast |work=Bloomberg |access-date=9 September 2017}} also known as the '''Catalan crisis''',{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41584864|title=Catalonia crisis in 300 words|date=30 October 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=4 November 2017|language=en-GB}} is an ongoing political conflict between the [[Government of Spain]] and the [[Generalitat de Catalunya]] under former [[President of the Generalitat of Catalonia|President]] [[Carles Puigdemont]]—the government of the autonomous community of Catalonia until 28 October 2017—over the issue of [[Catalan independence]]. It started after the law intending to allow the [[Catalan independence referendum, 2017|2017 Catalan independence referendum]] was denounced by the Spanish government under [[Prime Minister of Spain|Prime Minister]] [[Mariano Rajoy]] and subsequently suspended by the [[Constitutional Court of Spain|Constitutional Court]] until it ruled on the issue.{{cite news |last=Strange |first=Hannah |date=7 September 2017 |title=Spain's constitutional court suspends Catalan referendum law |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/09/07/catalonias-independence-referendum-intolerable-act-disobedience/ |work=The Daily Telegraph |access-date=9 September 2017}} Some international media outlets have described the events as "one of the worst political crises in modern Spanish history". Puigdemont's government announced that neither central Spanish authorities nor the courts would halt their plans and that it intended to hold the vote anyway, sparking a legal backlash that quickly spread from the Spanish and Catalan governments to [[Municipalities of Catalonia|Catalan municipalities]]—as local mayors were urged by the Generalitat to provide logistical support and help for the electoral process to be carried out—as well as to the Constitutional Court, the [[High Court of Justice of Catalonia]] and state prosecutors.{{cite news |date=9 September 2017 |title=Catalonia pushes Spain toward crisis |url=http://www.theleader.info/2017/09/09/catalonia-pushes-spain-toward-crisis/ |work=The Leader |access-date=9 September 2017}} By 15 September, as pro-Catalan independence parties began their referendum campaigns, the Spanish government had launched an all-out legal offensive to thwart the upcoming vote, including threats of a financial takeover of much of the Catalan budget, police seizing pro-referendum posters, pamphlets and leaflets which had been regarded as illegal and criminal investigations ordered on the over 700 local mayors who had publicly agreed to help stage the referendum.{{cite news |last=Hedgecoe |first=Guy |date=15 September 2017 |title=Spain's crisis sharpens as Catalonia referendum campaign begins |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/world/europe/spain-s-crisis-sharpens-as-catalonia-referendum-campaign-begins-1.3222468 |work=The Irish Times |location=Madrid |access-date=18 September 2017}}{{cite news |date=18 September 2017 |title=Spanish police confiscate Catalan referendum material |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/09/spanish-police-confiscate-catalan-referendum-material-170918080656349.html |work=Al Jazeera |access-date=18 September 2017}} Tensions between the two sides reached a critical point after Spanish police raided the Catalan government headquarters in Barcelona on 20 September, at the start of [[Operation Anubis]], and arrested fourteen senior Catalan officials. This led to protests outside the Catalan economy department which saw Civil Guard officers trapped inside the building for hours and several vehicles vandalized. The referendum was eventually held, albeit without meeting minimum standards for elections and amid low turnout and police crackdown resulting in hundreds injured.{{cite news|last1=Sanchez|first1=Ray|last2=Gallón|first2=Natalie|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/10/10/europe/catalonia-independence-declaration-delayed-spain/index.html|title=Catalonia's president puts off declaration of split from Spain|date=10 October 2017|work=CNN|location=Barcelona|access-date=16 October 2017}} On 10 October, Puigdemont ambiguously declared and suspended independence during a speech in the Parliament of Catalonia, arguing his move was directed at entering talks with Spain. The Spanish government required Puigdemont to clarify whether he had declared independence or not, to which it received no clear answer. A further requirement was met with an implicit threat from the Generalitat that it would lift the suspension on the independence declaration if Spain "continued its repression", in response to the imprisonment of the leaders of pro-independence [[Assemblea Nacional Catalana|Catalan National Assembly]] (ANC) and [[Òmnium Cultural]], accused of [[sedition]] by the [[Audiencia Nacional (Spain)|National Court]] because of their involvement in the 20 September events. On 21 October, it was announced by Prime Minister Rajoy that [[Constitution of Spain#Article 155|Article 155]] of the Spanish Constitution would be invoked, leading to [[direct rule over Catalonia]] by the Spanish government once approved by the [[Senate of Spain|Senate]]. On 27 October, the Catalan parliament voted in a secret ballot to [[Catalan Republic (2017)|unilaterally declare independence]] from Spain, with some deputies boycotting a vote considered illegal for violating the decisions of the Constitutional Court of Spain, as the lawyers of the Parliament of Catalonia warned.{{cite news|title=Un Parlament semivacío consuma en voto secreto la rebelión contra el Estado|url=http://www.elmundo.es/cataluna/2017/10/27/59f2feafe2704e491b8b48e2.html|accessdate=27 October 2017|newspaper=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|date=27 October 2017|language=es}}{{cite news|title=Los letrados del Parlament advierten de que la votación de la DUI es ilegal|url=http://www.20minutos.es/noticia/3171812/0/letrados-parlament-advierten-votacion-propuesta-dui-ilegal/|accessdate=28 October 2017|newspaper=[[20 minutos]]|date=27 October 2017|language=es}}{{cite news|title=PPC, PSC y Ciudadanos abandonarán el Parlament si se vota la resolución de Junts pel Sí y la CUP|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20171027/432386099496/ciudadanos-albiol-no-participaran-votacion-resolucion.html|accessdate=28 October 2017|newspaper=[[La Vanguardia]]|date=27 October 2017|language=es}} As a result, the government of Spain invoked the Constitution to remove the regional authorities and enforce direct rule the next day,{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41871476|title=Catalonia's longest week|date=4 November 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=7 November 2017|language=en-GB}} with a regional election being subsequently called for 21 December 2017 to elect a new Parliament of Catalonia.{{cite news |date=27 October 2017 |title=Catalonia independence: Rajoy dissolves Catalan parliament|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41783289 |work=BBC News |location=Barcelona, Madrid |access-date=27 October 2017}} Puigdemont and part of his cabinet fled to Belgium after being ousted, as the [[Spanish Attorney General]] pressed for charges of sedition, [[rebellion]] and misuse of public funds against them. ==Background== The recent increase in support for [[Catalan independence]] has its roots in a [[Constitutional Court of Spain|Constitutional Court]] ruling in 2010, which struck down parts of the regional [[Statute of Autonomy of Catalonia|2006 Statute of Autonomy]] that granted new powers of self-rule to the region. The ruling came after four years of deliberation concerning a constitutional appeal filed by the conservative [[People's Party (Spain)|People's Party]] (PP) under [[Mariano Rajoy]]—then the country's second-largest party, in opposition to the government of [[José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero]]'s [[Spanish Socialist Workers' Party]]—and was met with [[2010 Catalan autonomy protest|anger and street protests in Catalonia]].{{cite news |date=29 June 2010 |title=Spanish Constitutional Court cuts back Catalan Statute of Autonomy |url=https://www.nationalia.info/new/9216/spanish-constitutional-court-cuts-back-catalan-statute-of-autonomy |work=Nationalia |access-date=21 September 2017}}{{cite news |last=Govan |first=Fiona |date=29 June 2010 |title=Catalonia can call itself a 'nation', rules Spain's top court |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/spain/7861118/Catalonia-can-call-itself-a-nation-rules-Spains-top-court.html |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=Madrid |access-date=21 September 2017}} Shortly afterward the PP took power in Spain, and after a massive [[2012 Catalan independence demonstration|independence demonstration]] took place in Barcelona on 11 September 2012—[[National Day of Catalonia|Catalonia's National Day]]—the Catalan government under [[Artur Mas]] called a [[Catalan regional election, 2012|snap regional election]] and set out to initiate Catalonia's process towards independence.{{cite news |last=Burgen |first=Stephen |date=11 September 2012 |title=Catalan independence rally brings Barcelona to a standstill |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/sep/11/catalan-independence-rally-barcelona |work=The Guardian |location=Barcelona |access-date=21 September 2017}} After a pro-independence coalition formed by the [[Junts pel Sí]] alliance and the [[Popular Unity Candidacy]] won a slim majority in the Parliament in the [[Catalan regional election, 2015|2015 regional election]], [[Carles Puigdemont]] replaced Mas as President of the Generalitat. Puigdemont promised to organise a binding independence referendum based on results from a [[Catalan self-determination referendum, 2014|multi-question, non-binding vote in 2014]], when about 80% of those who voted were believed to have backed independence for the region, and up to 91.8% supported Catalonia becoming a state—albeit on an estimated turnout around or below 40%.{{cite news |last=Jackson |first=Patrick |date=14 September 2017 |title=Catalonia's collision course with Madrid |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-29478415 |work=BBC News |location=Barcelona, Madrid |access-date=15 September 2017}} The Catalan government invoked the [[Self-determination|right of people to self-determination]] and Catalonia's political, economical and cultural background to back up its proposal for a referendum on Catalan independence.{{cite news |last=Jones |first=Sam |date=9 June 2017 |title=Catalonia calls independence referendum for October |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jun/09/catalonia-calls-independence-referendum-for-october-spain |work=The Guardian |location=Madrid |access-date=20 September 2017}}{{cite news |date=15 July 2017 |title=Catalonia plans an independence vote whether Spain lets it or not |url=https://www.economist.com/news/europe/21724960-prime-minister-mariano-rajoy-says-vote-illegal-and-vows-block-it-catalonia-plans |work=The Economist |location=Madrid |access-date=20 September 2017}} The [[Government of Spain]], now with Mariano Rajoy as [[Prime Minister of Spain|Prime Minister]], opposed such a vote, arguing that any referendum on Catalan independence would go against the country's [[Spanish Constitution of 1978|1978 Constitution]], as it made no provision for a vote on self-determination. On 9 June 2017, Puigdemont announced that the planned independence referendum would be held on 1 October the same year. The Catalan government criticised the attitude of the Spanish government in refusing to negotiate a referendum and accused it of behaving undemocratically.{{cite news |date=9 June 2017 |title=Catalonia to hold self-determination referendum on October 1, 2017 |url=http://www.catalannews.com/politics/item/catalonia-to-hold-self-determination-referendum-on-october-1-2017 |agency=Catalan News Agency |location=Barcelona |access-date=20 September 2017}} ==Start of crisis== ===Referendum suspended=== [[File:DiadadelSi 5.jpg|left|thumb|Pro-independence supporters during a rally on 11 September 2017]] On 6 September 2017, the ruling [[Junts pel Sí]] (JxSí) coalition and its parliamentary partner, the [[Popular Unity Candidacy]] (CUP), passed the [[Law on the Referendum on Self-determination of Catalonia]] in the [[Parliament of Catalonia]] that was to provide the legal framework for the intended independence referendum scheduled for 1 October. The way in which the law had been pushed through Parliament became an issue of controversy. Catalan opposition parties accused JxSí and CUP of fast-tracking the law through parliament, not allowing them to appeal the law before being put up to vote.{{cite news |last=Puente |first=Arturo |date=8 September 2017 |title=El Parlament aprueba la ley para declarar la independencia tras el 1-O |url=https://www.eldiario.es/catalunya/politica/Parlament-Catalunya-aprueba-declarar-independencia_0_684182584.html |work=eldiario.es |location=Madrid |access-date=9 April 2018}} Some months later the Spanish Constitutional Court endorsed the reform of the Parliament regulation that allowed passing the law.{{cite news |last=Puente |first=Arturo |date=29 November 2017 |title=El Constitucional avala la reforma del reglamento del Parlament que impulsaron JxSí y la CUP |url=https://www.eldiario.es/catalunya/politica/Constitucional-reglamento-Parlament-JxSi-CUP_0_713229236.html |work=eldiario.es |location=Madrid |access-date=9 April 2018}}{{cite news |date=29 November 2017 |title=El TC avala la reforma del reglament del Parlament |url=https://www.ara.cat/politica/TC-declara-constitucional-reforma-reglament-Parlament_0_1915008642.html |work=Diari Ara |location=Barcelona |language=ca |access-date=9 April 2018}} Shortly after the parliamentary vote, in which most of the opposition MPs walked out from the chamber without voting on the bill, the Catalan regional government signed the decree calling the referendum.{{cite news |last=Jones |first=Sam |date=6 September 2017 |title=Catalonia to hold independence vote despite anger in Madrid |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/sep/06/spanish-government-condemns-catalonia-over-independence-referendum |work=The Guardian |location=Madrid |access-date=9 September 2017}}{{cite news |date=6 September 2017 |title=Catalan parliament passes controversial referendum law |url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2017/09/06/inenglish/1504711550_720781.html |work=El País |location=Barcelona, Madrid |access-date=9 September 2017}} The [[People's Party (Spain)|People's Party]]-led Spanish government under Prime Minister [[Mariano Rajoy]] announced that it would appeal the bill to the Constitutional Court, which agreed to hear all four of its unconstitutionality appeals and subsequently suspended the law and the referendum until it could rule upon the matter. Despite the referendum suspension, the Catalan government announced it would proceed with the vote anyway.{{cite news |date=7 September 2017 |title=Catalonia's parliament approves law aimed at independence from Spain |url=https://www.efe.com/efe/english/portada/catalonia-s-parliament-approves-law-aimed-at-independence-from-spain/50000260-3372462 |work=Efe |location=Madrid |access-date=9 September 2017}}{{cite news |last=Minder |first=Raphael |date=8 September 2017 |title=Catalonia Independence Bid Pushes Spain Toward Crisis |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/08/world/europe/spain-catalonia-independence.html?mcubz=0 |work=The New York Times |location=Barcelona |access-date=9 September 2017}} This prompted [[Spanish Attorney General|Attorney General]] [[José Manuel Maza]] to ask security forces to investigate possible preparations from the Catalan government to hold the vote, as well as announcing he would present criminal charges against members of both the regional parliament and government for voting and signing off the referendum. The national government proceeded to deploy a series of legal measures intended to nullify the referendum, while also warning local councils in Catalonia to either impede or paralyse efforts to carry out the vote.{{cite news |date=8 September 2017 |title=Spain Catalonia: Court blocks independence referendum |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41196677 |work=BBC News |access-date=9 September 2017}} Previously, local mayors had been given 48 hours by the regional government to confirm the availability of polling stations for 1 October.{{cite news |last=Noguer |first=Miquel |date=8 September 2017 |title=Spain's PM to Catalan secessionists: "Stop walking toward the abyss" |url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2017/09/07/inenglish/1504794086_268840.html?rel=mas |work=El País |location=Barcelona |access-date=9 September 2017}}{{cite news |date=7 September 2017 |title=Catalonian mayors prepare for separatist vote as Spain ramps up legal action |url=https://www.efe.com/efe/english/portada/catalonian-mayors-prepare-for-separatist-vote-as-spain-ramps-up-legal-action/50000260-3372251 |work=Efe |location=Barcelona |access-date=9 September 2017}} On 7 September and under a similar procedure as the day previously, pro-independence lawmakers in the Parliament of Catalonia passed the [[Law of transitional jurisprudence and foundation of the Republic|legal framework]] that was to prevail the Spanish one should a majority vote for the 'Yes' to independence choice. Within the next two days, nearly 74% of Catalan municipalities—comprising about 43% of the Catalan population—had agreed to provide the necessary polling stations for the referendum, whereas many of the most-populated urban areas—representing 24% of Catalan inhabitants—had voiced their opposition to the vote.{{cite news |last1=Galán |first1=Javier |last2=Alameda |first2=David |last3=Abad Liñán |first3=José Manuel |last4=Pueyo Busquets |first4=Jordi |date=7 September 2017 |title=¿Qué ayuntamientos han dicho ya sí o no al referéndum de Cataluña? |url=https://elpais.com/ccaa/2017/09/07/catalunya/1504795818_434503.html |language=Spanish |work=El País |location=Barcelona, Madrid |access-date=9 September 2017}} The largest city and capital of Catalonia, [[Barcelona]]—accounting for about 20% of the region's population—was caught in the middle, with its local mayor, [[Ada Colau]], refusing to make a statement whether the municipality would provide logistic support to the referendum or not while rejecting putting public servants at risk; she, however, voiced her support for the people's right to vote in a fair and legal referendum.{{cite news |last=Parra |first=Aritz |date=8 September 2017 |title=Catalan officials defy Madrid on independence vote |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/contested-future-catalonias-suspended-independence-vote-49698299 |work=ABC News |location=Madrid |access-date=9 September 2017}}{{cite news |last=Puente |first=Arturo |date=8 September 2017 |title=Colau pide garantías a la Generalitat para facilitar el 1-O |url=http://www.eldiario.es/catalunya/politica/Barcelona-cedera-locales-referendum_0_684532362.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=9 September 2017}} Concurrently, [[President of Catalonia]] [[Carles Puigdemont]], Vice-President [[Oriol Junqueras]], the entire Catalan government as well as parliamentary officials allowing the referendum law to be put to vote in Parliament—including Parliament Speaker [[Carme Forcadell]]—faced charges of disobedience, misusing public funds and making deliberately unlawful decisions as elected officials as the High Court of Justice of Catalonia agreed to hear the criminal complaints filled by state prosecutors.{{cite news |last1=Noguer |first1=Miquel |last2=Tena |first2=Berta |date=8 September 2017 |title=Prosecutors take action against Catalan officials after referendum law passed |url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2017/09/08/inenglish/1504865413_795013.html |work=El País |location=Barcelona, Madrid |access-date=9 September 2017}}{{cite news |last=Solé Altimira |first=Oriol |date=8 September 2017 |title=El TSJC admite la querella contra Puigdemont, Junqueras y todos los consellers por el referéndum |url=http://www.eldiario.es/catalunya/politica/Fiscalia-acusa-Puigdemont_0_684182580.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=9 September 2017}} ===Judicial and police action=== {{Main|Operation Anubis}} {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | footer = Protests in Barcelona after the arrest of fourteen Catalan government officials on 20 September. | image1 = 20Set Barcelona 14.jpg | width1 = 250 | image2 = Protestas-Conselleria-Economia-Generalitat-Guardia EDIIMA20170921 0115 22.jpg | width2 = 250 }} On 8 September the Attorney General of [[Catalonia]], [[José María Romero de Tejada]], presented two complaints to the [[High Court of Justice of Catalonia]] (TSJC) against him Government and the Bureau of Parliament for crimes of disobedience, [[Deception|prevarication]] and misappropriation of public funds, as announced the day before the [[Spanish Attorney General|Attorney General]] [[José Manuel Maza]]. These complaints included the guarantee request for the members of the Government as well as a request for a notification to all mayors of Catalonia to prevent any "personal or material resource, including local" resources being provided for the celebration of referendum The court was also asked to notify the Catalan media managers of the prohibition of inserting institutional advertising or propaganda of the referendum.{{Cite web|title=The criminal prosecution proceeds the Government and the Parliament table|url=http://www.ara.cat/politica/fiscalia-TSJC-querelles-Govern-Parlament-presentacio_0_1865813550.html|publisher=''Ara''|accessdate=27 November 2017|language=Catalan|date=8 September 2017}} These complaints were admitted by the TSJC on 14 September without accepting the request for a deposit for the members of the Government.{{Cite web|title=The TSJC avoids claiming a deposit to the members of the Government for the 1- O|url=http://www.ara.cat/politica/Tribunal-Superior-Garantiescat-voluntaris-referendum_0_1869413229.html|publisher='''Ara'''|accessdate=27 November 2017|language=Catalan|date=8 September 2017}} A decision on 13 September from Spain's public prosecutors to order a criminal probe of all local mayors who had publicly announced they would help stage the independence referendum—totalling over 700—came the day after the Constitutional Court had accepted the Spanish government's request to suspend the second of the two laws that had been approved by the secessionist majority in the Catalan parliament the previous week. The probe meant that prosecutors could choose to present criminal charges—or even arrest, if failing to answer the summons—local mayors who disobeyed the Constitutional Court's ruling. As part of a series of moves to block the Catalan referendum, prosecutors had also instructed police officials to seize ballot boxes, election flyers and other items that could be of use in the illegal vote, whereas the Constitutional Court had instructed regional government officials to show how they were preventing the vote from going ahead within a 48-hour deadline.{{cite news |date=13 September 2017 |title=Spain threatens to arrest over 700 Catalan pro-referendum mayors |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/09/13/spain-threatens-arrest-700-catalan-pro-referendum-mayors/ |work=The Daily Telegraph |access-date=14 September 2017}}{{cite news |date=14 September 2017 |title=Spain summons Catalan mayors over independence vote |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/09/spain-summons-catalan-mayors-independence-vote-170913153323027.html |work=Al Jazeera |access-date=14 September 2017}} In response, the Catalan government sent a letter to [[Ministry of the Treasury and Public Function (Spain)|Treasury Minister]] [[Cristóbal Montoro]] announcing that it would stop sending weekly financial accounts to Spain's central government, a previously-established obligation that was meant to verify whether the region was using public money for the promotion of its independence drive as well as a requirement for the region's access to a funding programme to autonomous communities established in 2012.{{cite news |date=14 September 2017 |title=Catalonia refuses to send weekly accounts to Madrid before referendum |url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-spain-politics-catalonia-funding/catalonia-refuses-to-send-weekly-accounts-to-madrid-before-referendum-idUKKCN1BP2FR |agency=Reuters |location=Madrid |access-date=14 September 2017}} The Spanish government then proceeded to take direct control of most of Catalonia's invoice payments.{{cite news |last1=Estévez Torreblanca |first1=Marina |last2=Carreño |first2=Belén |date=15 September 2017 |title=El Gobierno asume los pagos de las facturas catalanas |url=http://www.eldiario.es/economia/Gobierno_0_686981636.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=15 September 2017}}{{cite news |last1=Sixto Baquero |first1=Camilo |last2=Sérvulo González |first2=Jesús |date=14 September 2017 |title=Catalonia to central government ahead of referendum: No more spending reports |url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2017/09/14/inenglish/1505406245_501026.html |work=El País |location=Barcelona, Madrid |access-date=15 September 2017}} In a search on 19 September, Spanish police seized significant election material which had been in store by referendum organizers at the offices of a private delivery company in [[Terrassa]]. These included voting cards contained in envelopes with the Catalan government's logo.{{cite news |date=19 September 2017 |title=Catalonia referendum: Spanish raid deals blow to vote |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41325663 |work=BBC News |access-date=20 September 2017}} The next day, the [[Civil Guard (Spain)|Civil Guard]] raided Generalitat offices and arrested fourteen senior officials from the Catalan government—most notably, these included {{ill|Josep Maria Jové|ca|Josep Maria Jové i Lladó}}, deputy to regional Vice-President Oriol Junqueras.{{cite news |date=20 September 2017 |title=Catalonia referendum: Spain steps up raids to halt vote |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41331152 |work=BBC News |access-date=20 September 2017}}{{cite news |last1=Hernández |first1=José Antonio |last2=Carranco |first2=Rebeca |last3=García |first3=Jesús |date=20 September 2017 |title=Civil Guard raids Catalan government offices, arrests 14 over illegal referendum |url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2017/09/20/inenglish/1505891512_285586.html |work=El País |location=Barcelona, Madrid |access-date=20 September 2017}} This came after mayors from towns supporting the referendum were questioned in court by state prosecutors.{{cite news |last=Stone |first=Jon |date=20 September 2017 |title=Spanish police storm Catalan government buildings to stop independence referendum |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/catalonia-independence-referendum-catalan-police-storm-ministries-arrested-josep-maria-jov-a7956581.html |work=The Independent |access-date=20 September 2017}} Regional premier Carles Puigdemont condemned the actions as "anti-democratic and totalitarian", accusing the Spanish government of 'de facto' imposing a state of emergency and of suspending Catalonia's autonomy after it took effective control over Catalan finances.{{cite news |date=20 September 2017 |title=Catalan crisis: 'State of emergency' as Madrid cracks down on referendum by rounding up officials |url=http://www.thejournal.ie/catalan-referendum-2-3606676-Sep2017/ |work=The Journal |access-date=20 September 2017}} Public protests occurred in Barcelona after news of the arrests emerged, with left-wing political party [[Podemos (Spanish political party)|Podemos]] and Barcelona mayor Ada Colau joining the growing criticism of Mariano Rajoy's government crackdown on public servants, dubbing it as an "authoritarian regression". The previous day, the [[Congress of Deputies (Spain)|Congress of Deputies]] had voted down a motion from [[Citizens (Spanish political party)|Ciudadanos]] to support the Spanish government's response to the referendum, which was rejected by 166 votes to 158.{{cite news |last=Stone |first=Jon |date=20 September 2017 |title=Catalonia referendum: Catalonian government 'de facto' suspended by Spain, President of region says |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/catalonia-referendum-government-suspended-de-facto-independence-spain-madrid-government-raid-a7957046.html |work=The Independent |access-date=20 September 2017}}{{cite news |last1=Jones |first1=Sam |last2=Burgen |first2=Stephen |date=20 September 2017 |title=Catalan president says Madrid is suspending region's autonomy |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/sep/20/spain-guardia-civil-raid-catalan-government-hq-referendum-row |work=The Guardian |location=Madrid, Barcelona |access-date=20 September 2017}}{{cite news |last=Stothard |first=Michael |date=20 September 2017 |title=Spanish national police raid Catalan government headquarters |url=https://www.ft.com/content/0d0ec8ea-9dd7-11e7-8cd4-932067fbf946 |work=Financial Times |location=Madrid |access-date=20 September 2017}} Rajoy defended his government's actions in that "What we're seeing in Catalonia is an attempt to eliminate the constitution and the autonomous statute of Catalonia... Logically, the state has to react. There is no democratic state in the world that would accept what these people are trying to do. They've been warned and they know the referendum can't take place". Rajoy also called for the Catalonia government to give up its "escalation of radicalism and disobedience", calling for them to "Go back to the law and democracy" and dubbing the referendum a "chimera", as tens of thousands gathered in the streets of Barcelona and other Catalan cities to protest police actions.{{cite news |date=20 September 2017 |title=Catalonia referendum: Spain PM calls for 'escalation' to stop |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41342205 |work=Financial Times |location=Madrid |access-date=20 September 2017}}{{cite news |last=Marsden |first=Sam |date=20 September 2017 |title=Catalonia: Thousands take to streets of Barcelona to protest crackdown on separatists |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/catalan-protests-spain-referendum-independence-separatists-government-crackdown-a7958206.html |work=The Independent |location=Barcelona |access-date=20 September 2017}} The Spanish government did not rule out invoking Article 155 of the Spanish Constitution, which would allow the central government to adopt "the necessary measures to compel regional authorities to obey the law"—in practice, allowing for the autonomy's effective suspension and [[wikt:direct rule|direct rule]] of the region. On 21 September, the Catalan government acknowledged that the raid and arrests in the previous day severely hampered the referendum's logistics by preventing any alternative election data centre to be established in time for the vote to take place.{{cite news |last1=Toyer |first1=Julien |last2=Edwards |first2=Sam |date=21 September 2017 |title=Spanish crackdown has undermined Catalan independence bid, regional leader says |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-spain-politics-catalonia/spanish-crackdown-has-undermined-catalan-independence-bid-regional-leader-says-idUSKCN1BW1O1 |agency=Reuters |location=Madrid, Barcelona |access-date=21 September 2017}} Nonetheless, Catalan Vice-President Junqueras called for people to turn out and mobilise on 1 October, turning the social response into a "censure motion to Rajoy", stating that "If there is any possibility of change in Spain, democracy must triumph in Catalonia".{{cite news |last=Tomàs |first=Neus |date=20 September 2017 |title=20-S, golpe letal al referéndum |url=http://www.eldiario.es/catalunya/politica/golpe-letal-referendum_0_688731915.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=21 September 2017}}{{cite news |date=21 September 2017 |title=Junqueras: "La mejor moción de censura a Rajoy es el referéndum en Catalunya" |url=http://www.europapress.es/catalunya/noticia-junqueras-mejor-mocion-censura-rajoy-referendum-catalunya-20170921094657.html |language=Spanish |work=Europa Press |location=Barcelona |access-date=21 September 2017}} As street protests continued throughout Catalonia, additional police reinforcements were sent by the Spanish government to block any moves to hold the referendum on 1 October.{{cite news |date=22 September 2017 |title=Spain sends more police to block Catalonia referendum |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-spain-politics-catalonia-police/spain-sends-more-police-to-block-catalonia-referendum-idUSKCN1BX1GL |agency=Reuters |location=Madrid |access-date=23 September 2017}}{{cite news |last=Jones |first=Sam |date=22 September 2017 |title=Catalan leader accuses Spanish government of Franco-style crackdown |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/sep/22/catalan-leader-accuses-spanish-government-of-franco-style-crackdown |work=The Guardian |location=Barcelona |access-date=23 September 2017}} Spanish prosecutors formally accused some protesters in Barcelona of [[sedition]], after several Civil Guard patrol cars had been vandalised on Wednesday night.{{cite news |last1=Ortega Dolz |first1=Patricia |last2=Andrés |first2=Guillen |last3=Pérez |first3=Fernando Jesús |date=22 September 2017 |title=Spanish prosecutors formally accuse Barcelona protesters of sedition |url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2017/09/22/inenglish/1506091941_018182.html |work=El País |location=Barcelona, Madrid |access-date=23 September 2017}} By 23 September, the Spanish government announced that the [[Mossos d'Esquadra]]—the regional police force—were to be subordinated to a single command dependent of the Spanish government and that the [[Ministry of the Interior (Spain)|Interior Ministry]] would assume co-ordination over all security forces in Catalonia.{{cite news |date=23 September 2017 |title=El fiscal comunica a los Mossos que Interior asume el control de la seguridad en Catalunya |url=http://www.eldiario.es/catalunya/politica/toma-control-Mossos_0_689781167.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=23 September 2017}} The previous day, several hundred students had announced a permanent [[Occupation (protest)|occupation]] of the historic building of the [[University of Barcelona]], protesting the state's actions.{{cite news |date=22 September 2017 |title=El movimiento estudiantil anuncia la ocupación indefinida de la UB |url=http://www.elnacional.cat/es/politica/estudiantes-referendum-diagonal_194181_102.html |language=Spanish |work=El Nacional |access-date=23 September 2017}}{{cite news |date=23 September 2017 |title=Spain Takes Over Coordinating Police Work in Catalonia |url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2017/09/23/world/europe/ap-eu-spain-catalonia.html?mcubz=0 |work=The New York Times |location=Barcelona |access-date=23 September 2017}}{{cite news |date=23 September 2017 |title=Students occupy Barcelona university in support of secession |url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2017/09/23/students-occupy-barcelona-university-in-support-secession.html |work=Fox News Channel |location=Barcelona |access-date=23 September 2017}} ==Development== ===Referendum and subsequent events=== {{See also|Catalan independence referendum, 2017|2017 Catalan general strike}} [[File:Catalan general strike 2017.jpg|300px|thumb|left|Demonstration in [[Barcelona]] during the [[2017 Catalan general strike|general strike]] held in Catalonia on 3 October 2017.]] Despite the suspension, the Catalan referendum was held on 1 October 2017, as scheduled by the Generalitat. Over 12,000 officers from the [[National Police Corps]] and the [[Civil Guard (Spain)|Civil Guard]] were deployed throughout Catalonia in an effort to close off polling stations and seize all election material to prevent the vote from taking place. The Spanish government was forced to call off police raids after clashes with protesters resulted in two people seriously injured, one for a gum ball shot against the eye and the other one due to a heart attack. 893 civilians and 431 agents of the Nacional Police and the Civil Guard were reported to have been injured initially.{{Cite news|url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2017/10/02/hechos/1506963876_226068.html|title=¿Cuántos heridos hubo en realidad el 1-O?|last=País|first=El|date=3 October 2017|work=EL PAÍS|access-date=29 October 2017|language=es}}{{cite news|title=Over 840 people injured in Catalonia during referendum: Catalonia regional government |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-spain-politics-catalonia-injuries/over-840-people-injured-in-catalonia-during-referendum-catalonia-regional-government-idUSKCN1C61RX?il=0 |agency=[[Reuters]] |date=1 October 2017}} According to some Spanish media these previously reported figures may have been exaggerated.{{cite news|last1=Iglesias|first1=Leyre|title="Contamos como agresiones hasta las ansiedades por ver las cargas por televisión"|url=http://www.elmundo.es/cronica/2017/10/08/59d9237646163f58078b45c2.html|accessdate=11 October 2017|work=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|date=9 October 2017|language=es}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.elmundo.es/cronica/2017/10/08/59d9237646163f58078b45c2.html|title="Contamos como agresiones hasta las ansiedades por ver las cargas por televisión"|work=ELMUNDO|access-date=2018-03-02|language=es}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.redaccionmedica.com/autonomias/cataluna/-1-o-denuncian-que-salut-dio-ordenes-de-confundir-heridos-y-atendidos-7436|title=1-O: Denuncian que Salut dio órdenes de 'confundir' heridos y atendidos|work=Redacción Médica|access-date=2018-03-02|language=es-ES}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.libertaddigital.com/espana/2017-10-11/la-generalidad-dio-orden-de-confundir-heridos-y-atendidos-el-dia-del-referendum-ilegal-1276607386/|title=La Generalidad dio orden de confundir heridos y atendidos el día del referéndum ilegal|date=2017-10-11|work=Libertad Digital|access-date=2018-03-02|language=es-ES}} The Guardian's columnist, Peter Preston, said the number of injured "hadn't been independently checked" while he still described the police action as "violent and frightening".{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/08/catalonia-demo-injuries-fact-checking|title=Violence in Catalonia needed closer scrutiny in age of fake news|last=Preston|first=Peter|date=2017-10-08|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-02}} However, the Official College of Doctors of Barcelona (''Col·legi de Metges de Barcelona'') stated that "professionalism and independence of doctors can not be questioned because they act under a deontological code to attend and diagnose patients".{{cite news|title=El CCMC denuncia que no es pot posar en dubte la professionalitat i independència dels metges a l’hora de certificar els ferits el dia 1 d'octubre|url=https://www.comb.cat/cat/actualitat/noticies/noticies_fitxa.aspx?Id=paolJ%2f7syq7DWLn9lniZZA%3d%3d|accessdate=20 March 2018|work=Col·legi de Metges de Barcelona|date=13 October 2017|language=ca}} The judge who is currently investigating the accusations of police violence had already identified 218 people injured on October 10th, 20 of whom were police officers.{{cite news|title=Juez contabiliza 218 heridos en las cargas policiales en Barcelona el 1-O|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/vida/20171010/431965197269/juez-contabiliza-218-heridos-en-las-cargas-policiales-en-barcelona-el-1-o.html|accessdate=11 October 2017|work=[[La Vanguardia]]|agency=[[EFE]]|date=10 October 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Requeijo|first1=Alejandro|title=El juez que investiga las cargas policiales: "No era ilegal" votar el 1-O|url=https://www.elespanol.com/espana/politica/20171006/252225202_0.html|accessdate=11 October 2017|work=El Español|date=6 October 2017|language=es}} The events of 1 October sparked a public outcry in Catalonia, with hundreds of thousands taking to the streets to protest Spanish police violence. [[File:Estelada gegant a plaça major de Manresa.jpg|thumb|right|270px|Demonstration in [[Manresa]] on 3 October 2017.]] On 3 October 2017, as huge protest rallies and a [[2017 Catalan general strike|general strike]] took place in Catalonia, [[Felipe VI of Spain|King Felipe VI]] delivered an unusually strongly worded televised address in which he condemned the referendum organizers for acting "outside the law", accusing them of "unacceptable disloyalty" and of "eroding the harmony and co-existence within Catalan society itself". He also warned the referendum could put the economy of the entire north-east region of Spain at risk.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41493014|title=Catalan referendum: Vote illegal – Spain's King Felipe|date=3 October 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=3 October 2017}}{{cite news |last=Jones |first=Sam |date=3 October 2017 |title=King Felipe: Catalonia's authorities have 'scorned' all Spaniards with referendum |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/03/king-felipe-catalan-authorities-have-scorned-all-spaniards-with-referendum |work=The Guardian |location=Barcelona |access-date=4 October 2017}}{{cite news |last1=Clarke |first1=Hillary |last2=Rebaza |first2=Claudia |last3=Soares |first3=Soa |date=3 October 2017 |title=King of Spain accuses Catalan leaders of 'unacceptable disloyalty' |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/10/03/europe/catalonia-general-strike-protests-barcelona/index.html |work=CNN |access-date=4 October 2017}} Reactions to the King's speech were mixed. Party officials from the [[People's Party (Spain)|PP]] and [[Citizens (Spanish political party)|Ciudadanos]] praised the King's "commitment to legality",{{cite news |date=3 October 2017 |title=El PP destaca que el rey 'se ha vuelto a comprometer con la legalidad' |url=http://www.eldiario.es/catalunya/politica/MINUTO-Diada_13_685361458_13165.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=4 October 2017}} whereas leaders from [[Unidos Podemos]] and [[Catalunya en Comú]] criticised it as "unworthy and irresponsible", paving the way for a harsh intervention in Catalan autonomy.{{cite news |last=Gil |first=Andrés |date=3 October 2017 |title=El discurso del rey enciende a Unidos Podemos y los 'comunes' |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/discurso-rey-enciende-Unidos-Podemos-comunes_0_693281813.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=4 October 2017}} [[Spanish Socialist Workers' Party|PSOE]]'s leaders expressed support for the King's words in public, but were reported to be privately dissatisfied that the King had not made any call to encourage understanding or dialogue between the Spanish and Catalan governments.{{cite news |date=3 October 2017 |title=Dirigentes socialistas echan en falta una llamada al entendimiento en las palabras del rey |url=http://www.eldiario.es/catalunya/politica/MINUTO-Diada_13_685361458_13171.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=4 October 2017}} On 5 October the [[Constitutional Court of Spain]] suspended a future parliamentary session (scheduled for 9 October) that was planned in order to push for a Declaration of Independence.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41514398|title=Spain court halts independence move by MPs|date=5 October 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=5 October 2017}} On 5 October, [[Banco Sabadell]], the second-largest bank based in Catalonia, announced its decision to move its legal headquarters out of the region amid economic uncertainty over the future of Catalonia's political situation ahead of a projected [[unilateral declaration of independence]] the ensuing week, which had seen sharp falls in the group's share prices the previous day and rating agencies downgrading the region. Concurrently, [[CaixaBank]], the biggest bank in the region and the third largest in Spain, also announced it was considering redomiciling outside Catalonia.{{cite news|last1=Stothard|first1=Michael|last2=Buck|first2=Tobias|url=https://www.ft.com/content/daada4cc-a9b4-11e7-93c5-648314d2c72c|title=Big bank to move headquarters out of Catalonia|date=5 October 2017|work=Financial Times|location=Madrid, Barcelona|access-date=6 October 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/catalonia-banks-move-location-independence-catalan-protests-fear-customer-deposits-a7985951.html|title=Catalonia banks prepare to move amid fears of customer exodus|date=6 October 2017|work=Independent|access-date=6 October 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Petroff|first1=Alanna|last2=Liakos|first2=Chris|url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/10/05/investing/catalonia-banks-relocation-independence-spain/index.html|title=Top bank moving HQ out of Catalonia over threat of split from Spain|date=6 October 2017|work=CNN Money|access-date=6 October 2017}} This sparked a massive business exit in the ensuing hours, with companies such as [[Abertis]], [[Gas Natural]], [[Grifols]], [[Fersa Energias Renovables]], [[Agbar]], [[Freixenet]], [[Codorníu]], [[Idilia Foods]], [[San Miguel Beer]] and [[Planeta Group]] also announcing or considering their intention to move their HQs out of Catalonia. The Spanish government announced on Friday 6 October that it would issue a decree allowing companies based in Catalonia to move out of the region without holding a shareholders' meeting.{{cite news|last1=Linsell|first1=Katie|last2=Duarte|first2=Esteban|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/catalonia-banks-move-location-independence-catalan-protests-fear-customer-deposits-a7985951.html|title=Catalonia banks prepare to move amid fears of customer exodus|date=6 October 2017|work=Independent|access-date=6 October 2017}}{{cite news|last=Burguen|first=Stephen|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/06/catalonia-business-independence-spanish-government|title=Catalonia seeks to prevent business exit in event of independence declaration|date=6 October 2017|work=The Guardian|location=Barcelona|access-date=6 October 2017}}{{cite news |last=Muñoz Vélez |first=Antonio |date=6 October 2017 |title=Diez cotizadas catalanas pueden usar el decreto del Gobierno para permitir mudanzas exprés |url=http://www.eldiario.es/economia/cotizadas-catalanas-utilizar-Gobierno-permitir_0_694330881.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=6 October 2017}}{{cite news |date=7 October 2017 |title=Aguas de Barcelona (Agbar) también decide trasladar su sede social de Barcelona a Madrid
