de 268 en un solo día |url=http://www.elmundo.es/economia/2017/10/20/59e9ccbbca4741af068b4611.html |language=Spanish |work=El Mundo |access-date=21 October 2017}} Simultaneously, far-right groups increasingly took to the streets throughout Spain in a quest to defend Spanish unity, with some gatherings leading to violent scuffles in Barcelona and Valencia. This sparked concerns among analysts that the Catalan crisis could lead to a rise of the far-right in Spain after decades on the margins. The Mossos d'Esquadra were put under investigation for disobedience, accused of not complying with a command from the [[High Court of Justice of Catalonia]] to prevent the referendum and with their pasivity allowing polling stations to open.{{cite news |date=1 October 2017 |title=1-O. La pasividad de los Mossos y las posteriores cargas policiales marcan un día de tensión con votaciones sin garantías |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/pasividad-Mossos-posteriores-policiales-votaciones_0_692581270.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=16 October 2017}}{{cite news |last1=G. Labat |first1=Jesús |last2=Vázquez |first2=Ángeles|date=1 October 2017 |title=Siete jueces investigan a los Mossos por desobediencia al no frenar el 1-O |url=http://www.elperiodico.com/es/politica/20171001/un-juez-de-lleida-investiga-a-los-mossos-por-desobedienca-el-1-o-6324248 |language=Spanish |work=El Periódico de Catalunya |location=Barcelona, Madrid |access-date=16 October 2017}}{{cite news |date=4 October 2017 |title=Spanish judge calls on Catalan police chief to testify in sedition probe |url=https://www.efe.com/efe/english/portada/spanish-judge-calls-on-catalan-police-chief-to-testify-in-sedition-probe/50000260-3398503 |work=EFE |access-date=16 October 2017}} [[File:Cultural-ANC-Jordi-Conselleria-Economia EDIIMA20170922 0665 19.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Cultural-ANC-Jordi-Conselleria-Economia EDIIMA20170922 0665 19|The presidents of [[Òmnium Cultural]] and [[Assemblea Nacional Catalana|ANC]], [[Jordi Cuixart]] and [[Jordi Sànchez i Picanyol|Jordi Sànchez]], on top of one of the [[Guardia Civil (Spain)|Civil Guard]] vehicles vandalized during the protests in front of the Catalan economy department on 20 September 2017 in Barcelona.]] In an ambiguous speech during a parliamentary session in the Parliament of Catalonia on 10 October, Puigdemont declared that "Catalonia had earned the right to be an independent state" and that he defended "the mandate of the people of Catalonia to become an independent republic". However, he immediately announced that parliament would suspend a formal declaration of independence in order to pursue dialogue with the Spanish government. Puigdemont and other pro-independence deputies then signed a symbolic declaration of independence with no legal effect. Puigdemont's move came after pressure resulting from the business exit on the previous days as well as pleas from Barcelona's mayor [[Ada Colau]] and European Council President [[Donald Tusk]] urging him to step back from declaring independence.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41574172|title=Catalonia independence declaration signed and suspended|date=10 October 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=16 October 2017}} This was met with disappointment from thousands of pro-independence supporters who had gathered nearby to watch the session on giant screens,{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Sam|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/10/catalan-government-suspends-declaration-of-independence|title=Catalan government suspends declaration of independence|date=10 October 2017|work=The Guardian|location=Barcelona|access-date=16 October 2017}} as well as criticism from the CUP, who voiced their discontent at Puigdemont's decision not to proclaim a Catalan republic right away and did not rule out abandoning the Parliament until the signed declaration of independence was effective.{{cite news |date=10 October 2017 |title=La CUP lanza un ultimátum a Puigdemont y podría abandonar el Parlament |url=http://www.eleconomista.es/politica-eleconomista/noticias/8666472/10/17/La-CUP-responde-a-Puigdemont-Hoy-hemos-venido-a-proclamar-la-Republica.html |language=Spanish |work=El Economista |access-date=16 October 2017}} On 17 October, the [[Audiencia Nacional (Spain)|National Court]] ordered [[Jordi Sànchez i Picanyol|Jordi Sànchez]] and [[Jordi Cuixart]]—leaders of pro-independence groups [[Assemblea Nacional Catalana|Catalan National Assembly]] (ANC) and [[Òmnium Cultural]]—to be [[Preventive detention|preventively put into jail]] without bail pending an investigation into alleged [[sedition]] for having played central roles in orchestrating massive protests aimed at hindering Civil Guard activity.{{cite news|last=Fotheringham|first=Alasdair|date=16 October 2017|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/catalonia-independence-leaders-jailed-spain-judge-sedition-jordi-sanchez-jordi-cuixart-latest-news-a8004001.html|title=Catalonia: Spanish judge jails two independence leaders for possible sedition|work=The Independent|location=Madrid|access-date=20 October 2017}}{{cite news|last=Hannah|first=Strange|date=16 October 2017|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/10/16/two-catalan-independence-leaders-taken-custody-spanish-government/|title=Two Catalan independence leaders taken into custody by Spanish national court|work=The Telegraph|location=Barcelona|access-date=20 October 2017}}{{cite news|date=17 October 2017|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/17/madrid-jails-catalan-separatist-leaders-jordi-cuixart-and-jordi-sanchez-pending-investigation|title=Spain High Court jails Catalan separatist leaders pending investigation|work=The Guardian|location=Madrid|access-date=20 October 2017}} They were accused of leading the protest of tens of thousands of people that surrounded the Catalan economy department offices on 20–21 September 2017 heeding a call made by Òmnium Cultural and ANC, during which three vehicles of the Civil Guard were vandalised and their occupants forced to flee into the Economy Department building, a [[court clerk]] remained trapped until midnight inside the building and had to flee by the roof, while several agents were trapped throughout the night as demonstrators shouted outside "You won't get out!".{{cite news|last=Badcock|first=James|date=4 October 2017|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/10/04/catalonias-police-chief-faces-sedition-charge-protest-reaction/|title=Catalonia's police chief faces sedition charge for 'allegedly failing to follow orders' ahead of referendum|work=The Telegraph|location=Madrid}}{{cite news|last=Pinheiro|first=Marcos|url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/Sanchez-Cuixart-actuaron-Guardia-Civil_0_698180621.html|title=Las claves del auto de Sànchez y Cuixart: actuaron contra la Guardia Civil para "proteger" a altos cargos|date=17 October 2017|language=Spanish|work=eldiario.es}}{{cite news|date=22 September 2017|url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/Fiscalia-Audiencia-Nacional-Guardia-Civil_0_689431648.html|title=La Fiscalía denuncia por sedición en la Audiencia Nacional los incidentes de Barcelona tras las detenciones|language=Spanish|work=eldiario.es}}{{cite web|url=https://www.elespanol.com/espana/tribunales/20171014/254225123_0.html|title=El testimonio que puede llevar a prisión a Trapero: "Sentí terror y humillación"|date=15 October 2017|publisher=El Español|access-date=27 October 2017|language=es}} The Civil Guard agents cornered into the building made 6 calls for help to the autonomous police force of Catalonia [[Mossos d'Esquadra]] which were ignored, the first of them performed at 9:14 am with the subject: "Urgent - Request for support to Mossos".{{cite web|url=http://www.antena3.com/programas/espejo-publico/noticias/desvelan-las-6-llamadas-de-auxilio-de-la-guardia-civil-a-los-mossos_2017100659d744c70cf29f7c62db1481.html|title=Desvelan las 6 llamadas de auxilio de la Guardia Civil a los Mossos|website=[[Antena 3 (Spain)|Antena 3]]|accessdate=27 October 2017|date=6 October 2017|language=Spanish}} According to the judge the actions of Sànchez and Cruixat are into the scope of sedition, a [[felony]] regulated by the article 544 and subsequents of the Spanish [[Criminal Code]]:{{cite web|url=http://www.elperiodico.com/es/politica/20171017/delito-sedicion-que-es-codigo-penal-6344514|title=¿Qué es el delito de sedición? Así lo regula el Código Penal|date=17 October 2017|publisher=El Periódico|access-date=27 October 2017|language=es}} {{bquote|Conviction for sedition shall befall those who, without being included in the felony of rebellion, public and tumultuously rise up to prevent, by force or outside the legal channels, application of the laws, or any authority, official corporation or public officer from lawful exercise of the duties thereof or implementation of the resolutions thereof, or of administrative or judicial resolutions.|source=Article 544 of the Spanish Criminal Code.{{cite act |title=Criminal Code Organic Law of 1995 |type=Organic Law |number=10 |work=[[Boletín Oficial del Estado|Official State Gazette]] |language=Spanish |date={{date|1995-11-23|mdy}} |url=https://www.boe.es/buscar/act.php?id=BOE-A-1995-25444 |accessdate=28 October 2017}}}} Pro-independence politicians and organizations, including Catalan President Carles Puigdemont, have referred to Cuixart and Sànchez as political prisoners.{{cite news|date=16 October 2017|url=http://www.catalannews.com/politics/item/we-have-political-prisoners-again-says-catalan-president|title="We have political prisoners again", says Catalan president|work=Catalan News|access-date=17 October 2017}} The Spanish Justice Minister [[Rafael Catalá]] argued that they were not "political prisoners" but "imprisoned politicians".{{citeweb|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-18/political-prisoner-or-jailed-politician-it-s-catalan-feud-spin|title=Political Prisoner or Jailed Politician? It’s Catalans’ Spin Battle With Spain|date=18 October 2017|accessdate=28 October 2017}} An article published in ''[[El País]]'' argued that according to the criteria established by the [[Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe]] (PACE) Sànchez and Cuixart could not be considered "political prisoners".{{Cite news|date=18 October 2017|url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2017/10/18/inenglish/1508325235_772160.html|title=The "Jordis" are not political prisoners – here’s why|work=El País|location=Madrid|access-date=19 October 2017}} [[Amnesty International]] issued an official statement considering the charge of sedition and the preventive imprisonment as "excessive" and called for their immediate release, but several days later made it clear that it did not consider them "political prisoners".{{cite web|date=18 October 2017 |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/eur41/7308/2017/en/ |title=Spain: charges for sedition and pre-trial detention against Jordi Cuixart and Jordi Sanchez are excessive|work=Amnesty International|accessdate=24 October 2017}}{{cite news |title=Amnistía no ve como presos políticos a los dirigentes catalanes detenidos |url= http://www.elmundo.es/cataluna/2017/11/08/5a033877e5fdea2e408b45d0.html|work= [[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|date= 8 November 2017|access-date= 8 November 2017 }} Some Catalan media, such as ''[[La Vanguardia]]'', reported that footage from the incident showed Cuixart and Sànchez trying to call off the protests, contradicting that part of the judicial order imprisoning them which said that they had not tried "to call off the demonstration".{{cite news|last=Calvet|first=Josep Maria|date=17 October 2017|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20171017/432142495111/video-jordi-cuixart-jordi-sanchez-disolver-manifestacion-economia.html|title=Un vídeo muestra cómo Cuixart y Sànchez intentaron disolver la manifestación de Economia|language=Spanish|work=La Vanguardia|access-date=18 October 2017}} ===Independence declaration and direct rule=== {{See also|Catalan declaration of independence}} On 11 October, after an extraordinary cabinet meeting intended to address the events on the previous day, Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy announced he was formally requiring the Catalan government to confirm whether it had declared independence before 16 October at 10{{nbsp}}am, with a further 3-day deadline until 19 October to revoke all deemed illegal acts if an affirmative answer—or no answer at all—was obtained.{{cite news |last=Ponce de León |first=Rodrigo |date=11 October 2017 |title=El Gobierno exige que Puigdemont aclare su posición sobre la independencia antes del lunes |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/Rajoy-democracia-momentos-historia-reciente_0_696081134.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=16 October 2017}} This requirement was a formal requisite needed to trigger article 155 of the Spanish Constitution, a so-called "nuclear option" that would allow the Spanish government to suspend Catalonia's political autonomy and impose direct rule from Madrid.{{cite news |last=Ponce de León |first=Rodrigo |date=11 October 2017 |title=Rajoy anuncia el requerimiento a la Generalitat previo a la aplicación del artículo 155 |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/Rajoy_0_696080511.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=16 October 2017}}{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/spain-politics-catalonia-government/spain-moves-towards-activating-nuclear-option-on-catalonia-crisis-idUSE8N1AD01F|title=Spain moves towards activating "nuclear option" on Catalonia crisis|date=11 October 2017|work=Reuters|access-date=16 October 2017}}{{cite news|last=Rogers|first=Jon|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/world/865153/Catalonia-independence-referendum-Mariano-Rajoy-Article-155-Puigdemont|title=Catalonia crisis: Rajoy opens way to suspending region's self-rule|date=11 October 2017|work=Daily Express|access-date=16 October 2017}} Pressure mounted within the pro-independence coalition as the CUP demanded an unambiguous affirmation of Catalan independence, threatening to withdraw its parliamentary support from Puigdemont's government if he rescinded his independence claim.{{cite news|last=McLaughlin|first=Kelly|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-4981996/Catalonia-s-separatist-movement-danger-splitting.html|title=Catalan leader has until Monday morning to tell Madrid whether he did or didn't declare independence as Spain teeters on verge of splitting|date=15 October 2017|work=Daily Mail|access-date=16 October 2017}} In his formal response to Rajoy's requirement hurrying the initial five-day deadline, Puigdemont failed to clarify whether independence had been declared and instead called for negotiations over the following two months.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41632084|title=Catalonia leader Puigdemont fails to clarify independence bid|date=16 October 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=16 October 2017}}{{cite news|last=Vallespín|first=Ivanna|url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2017/10/16/inenglish/1508138246_000760.html|title=Puigdemont letter fails to provide clear answer on independence declaration|date=16 October 2017|work=El País|access-date=16 October 2017}} The Spanish government replied that this was not a valid response to its requirement and doubted that Puigdemont's offer for dialogue was sincere due to his lack of "clarity".{{cite news |date=16 October 2017 |title=El Gobierno cree que la carta de Puigdemont "parece que no responde a lo que se le ha solicitado" |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/Gobierno-considera-valida-respuesta-Puigdemont_0_697830296.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=16 October 2017}}{{cite news |last=Ponce de León |first=Rodrigo |date=16 October 2017 |title=El Gobierno duda de la oferta de diálogo de Puigdemont y pone en marcha el segundo requerimiento |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/Gobierno_0_697830345.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=16 October 2017}} The refusal from the Catalan government to either confirm or deny independence triggered a second deadline for them to backtrack before direct rule was imposed.{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Sam|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/16/catalan-president-carles-puigdemont-ignores-madrids-ultimatum|title=Catalan president Carles Puigdemont ignores Madrid's ultimatum|date=16 October 2017|work=The Guardian|location=Madrid|access-date=16 October 2017}}{{cite news|last=Couzens|first=Gerard|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/world/866931/Catalonia-latest-news-independence-Puigdemont-Spain-direct-rule|title=Furious Spain sets Catalonia new deadline as it REFUSES to confirm independence|date=16 October 2017|work=Daily Express|access-date=16 October 2017}} The Spanish government subsequently offered to abort the incoming move to suspend self-rule if the Catalan government called for a regional election, but this was ruled out by the latter.{{cite news|last1=Mármol|first1=Iolanda|last2=Martín|first2=Patricia|date=18 October 2017|url=http://www.elperiodico.com/es/politica/20171018/gobierno-psoe-155-elecciones-6361303|title=El Gobierno frenaría el artículo 155 si Puigdemont convocase elecciones autonómicas|language=Spanish|work=El Periódico de Catalunya|location=Madrid|access-date=20 October 2017}} {{bquote|If a self-governing community does not fulfil the obligations imposed upon it by the constitution or other laws, or acts in a way that is seriously prejudicial to the general interest of Spain, the government may take all measures necessary to compel the community to meet said obligations, or to protect the above-mentioned general interest.|source=Article 155 of the [[Spanish Constitution of 1978]].}} On 19 October, Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy confirmed that the Spanish government would trigger Article 155 and move to suspend Catalonia's autonomy after a cabinet meeting scheduled for 21 October, following a letter from Puigdemont in which he said that the independence declaration remained suspended but that the Catalan parliament could choose to vote on it if Spain continued its "repression".{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41678086|title=Spain moves to suspend Catalan autonomy|date=19 October 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=19 October 2017}} Subsequently, Rajoy announced the Spanish government would take direct control over the Generalitat of Catalonia, proceeding to remove Puigdemont and the entire Catalan government from their offices and call a regional election within six months, pending [[Senate of Spain|Senate]] approval.{{cite news|last=Ponce de León|first=Rodrigo|url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/Rajoy-activa-intervenir-Catalunya_0_699580194.html|title=Rajoy aprueba la intervención completa de Catalunya para cesar al Govern y convocar elecciones|date=21 October 2017|language=Spanish|work=eldiario.es|access-date=21 October 2017}}{{cite news |last=Burgen |first=Stephen |date=21 October 2017 |title=Catalonia crisis escalates as Spain set to impose direct rule within days |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/21/catalonai-crisis-spain-rajoy-direct-rule |work=The Guardian |location=Barcelona |access-date=21 October 2017}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41704759|title=Catalonia independence: Spain pushes to remove leaders|date=21 October 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=21 October 2017}} [[File:Comisión Especial del Senado Ate. 155 C.E. (2).jpg|thumb|Special Senate Commission on the Invocation of Article 155 of the Spanish Constitution (presidency).]] On 26 October, one day ahead of the scheduled enforcement of Article 155 by the Spanish Senate, it was announced that Puigdemont had chosen to dissolve the Parliament of Catalonia within the coming hours and call for an emergency snap election on or around 20 December in order to prevent direct rule from [[Madrid]].{{cite news |last=García Pagán |first=Isabel |date=26 October 2017 |title=Puigdemont convocará elecciones en Catalunya para el miércoles 20 de diciembre |url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20171026/432364601449/puigdemont-elecciones-articulo-155-catalunya.html |language=Spanish |work=La Vanguardia |access-date=26 October 2017}} This move sparked an outcry within pro-independence ranks, as they wished to hold a vote for a [[unilateral declaration of independence]] in response to the Spanish government's move to trigger Article 155.{{cite news |last=Pardo Torregrosa |first=Iñaki |date=26 October 2017 |title=Dimiten los diputados Albert Batalla y Jordi Cuminal del PDeCAT por la convocatoria de elecciones |url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20171026/432367324018/dimisiones-junts-pel-si-diputados-parlament-catalunya.html |language=Spanish |work=La Vanguardia |access-date=26 October 2017}}{{cite news |last=B. García |first=Luis |date=26 October 2017 |title=La CUP se irrita con el nuevo rumbo de Puigdemont hacia las elecciones autonómicas |url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20171026/432367324018/dimisiones-junts-pel-si-diputados-parlament-catalunya.html |language=Spanish |work=La Vanguardia |access-date=26 October 2017}} In the end Puigdemont chose not to dissolve Parliament, allegedly because of the Spanish government's refusal to call off the Article 155 procedure even though an election was called by Puigdemont.{{cite news |last1=Tomàs |first1=Newus |last2=Puente |first2=Arturo |date=26 October 2017 |title=Puigdemont no convoca elecciones tras fracasar la negociación con el Gobierno para retirar el 155 |url=http://www.eldiario.es/catalunya/politica/Puigdemont-convocara-elecciones-declaracion-independencia_0_701330740.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=26 October 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Dewan|first1=Angela|last2=Rebaza|first2=Claudia|date=26 October 2017|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/10/26/europe/catalonia-spain-puigdemont-independence/index.html|title=Catalan leader stumbles in bid for independence from Spain|work=CNN|access-date=26 October 2017}} A debate over a possible declaration of independence then went ahead as planned in the Parliament of Catalonia later that day and into the next morning,{{cite news |date=26 October 2017 |title=Catalan crisis: Regional MPs debate Spain takeover bid|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41760832|work=BBC|access-date=27 October 2017}} simultaneous to the Spanish Senate debating the enforcement of Article 155.{{cite news |date=27 October 2017 |title=Catalan crisis: Spain PM Rajoy demands direct rule|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41771294|work=BBC|access-date=27 October 2017}} At the end of the debate, the Catalan parliament voted for a [[unilateral declaration of independence]], by secret ballot, which was backed 70–10, with two MPs casting a blank ballot, with all MPs from [[Citizens (Spanish political party)|Citizens]], the [[Socialists' Party of Catalonia]] and the [[People's Party of Catalonia|People's Party]] boycotting the vote because of its illegality for violating the decisions of the [[Constitutional Court of Spain]], as the lawyers of the [[Parliament of Catalonia]] warned.{{cite news|title=Catalan parliament declares independence from Spain|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41780116|accessdate=27 October 2017|work=BBC|date=27 October 2017}} [[File:Manifestació «Llibertat presos polítics. Som República» 11-11-2017 07.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Demonstration under the slogan "Freedom for Political Prisoners, We are a Republic" on 11 November 2017]] Subsequently, on 28 October, Mariano Rajoy dismissed the [[Executive Council of Catalonia]], dissolved the [[Parliament of Catalonia]] and called a [[Catalan regional election, 2017|snap regional election]] for 21 December 2017, after obtaining the Senate endorsement to the invoking of Article 155,{{cite news |last=Ponce de León |first=Rodrigo |date=27 October 2017 |title=Rajoy cesa a Puigdemont y su Govern y convoca elecciones para el 21 de diciembre |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/Rajoy-cesa-Puigdemont-Govern_0_701680927.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=27 October 2017}} and handed coordination over [[Generalitat of Catalonia]] functions to Deputy Prime Minister [[Soraya Sáenz de Santamaría]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41788406|title=Soraya Sáenz de Santamaría - Madrid's enforcer for Catalonia|date=28 October 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=28 October 2017|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/world/872242/spain-catalonia-independence-latest-deputy-prime-minister-control-rajoy|title=Spain takes charge of Catalonia- Deputy PM handed CONTROL of region amid fears of violence|last=Mansfield|first=Katie|date=28 October 2017|work=Express.co.uk|access-date=28 October 2017|language=en}} On 30 October, as [[Spanish Attorney General]] [[José Manuel Maza]] called for charges of [[rebellion]], [[sedition]] and [[embezzlement]] against Puigdemont and other Catalan leaders,{{cite news |last=Guindal |first=Carlota |date=30 October 2017 |title=La Fiscalía se querella contra Puigdemont y el Govern por rebelión y sedición |url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20171030/432485190372/fiscal-maza-querella-puigdemont-junqueras.html |language=Spanish |work=La Vanguardia |access-date=30 October 2017}}{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Sam|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/30/spanish-prosecutor-calls-for-rebellion-charges-against-catalan-leaders|title=Spanish prosecutor calls for rebellion charges against Catalan leaders|date=30 October 2017|work=The Guardian|location=Barcelona|access-date=30 October 2017}} it transpired that the ousted President and five of his ministers had fled to [[Belgium]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41811649|title=Sacked Catalan leader 'in Belgium'|date=30 October 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=31 October 2017|language=en-GB}} Puigdemont, however, declared that he was not in Belgium "to seek asylum" and that he would respect the 21 December election, but also noting that he would not return home until "a fair judicial process was guaranteed" in Spain.{{cite news|last1=Rankin|first1=Jennifer|last2=Burguen|first2=Stephen|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/31/catalonia-ex-president-puigdemont-belgium-asylum-independence|title=Catalonia crisis: deposed leader Puigdemont says he'll respect elections|date=31 October 2017|work=The Guardian|location=Brussels, Barcelona|access-date=31 October 2017}}{{cite news|last=Stone|first=Jon|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/carles-puigdemont-catalonia-cannot-return-spain-vengeance-independence-brussels-latest-updates-a8029216.html|title=Carles Puigdemont says he can't return to Catalonia because Spain is intent on 'vengeance'|date=31 October 2017|work=The Independent|location=Brussels|access-date=31 October 2017}} Concurrently, lack of civil unrest and work resuming as normal throughout Catalonia showed direct rule from Madrid taking hold, with Spanish authorities reasserting administrative control over Catalan territory with little resistance.{{cite news|last1=Tadeo|first1=Maria|last2=Strauss|first2=Marine|last3=Duarte|first3=Esteban|date=30 October 2017|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-30/no-sign-of-catalan-leader-as-spanish-officials-take-back-control|title=Catalonia Bows to Spanish Authority as Rajoy's Strategy Prevails|work=Bloomberg|access-date=30 October 2017}}{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-spain-politics-catalonia/work-resumes-normally-in-catalonia-as-spain-enforces-direct-rule-idUSKBN1CZ0IP?il=0|title=Work resumes normally in Catalonia as Spain enforces direct rule|date=30 October 2017|agency=Reuters|location=Barcelona, Madrid|access-date=30 October 2017}} On 31 October, the independence declaration was suspended by the [[Constitutional Court of Spain]].{{cite news |date=31 October 2017 |title=El Constitucional suspende la declaración de independencia de Catalunya |url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/Constitucional-suspende-declaracion-independencia-Catalunya_0_703080059.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=31 October 2017}} Spain's [[Audiencia Nacional (Spain)|National Court]] ({{lang-es|link=no|Audiencia Nacional}}) summoned Puigdemont and 13 other members of his dismissed government to appear on 2 November to respond to the criminal charges pressed against them.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41825030|title=Catalan independence: Spain high court summons dismissed leader|date=31 October 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=31 October 2017}} It was later ordered by the judge that eight members of the deposed Catalan government—including Puigdemont's deputy and [[Republican Left of Catalonia|ERC]] leader, [[Oriol Junqueras]]—be remanded in custody without bail after testifying for posing a flight risk, with a ninth—[[Santi Vila]]—being granted a €50,000 bail. Spanish prosecutors sought a [[European Arrest Warrant]] for Puigdemont and four other members who had remained in Belgium and refused to attend the hearing.{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Sam|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/nov/02/spanish-court-question-catalonia-separatists-except-puigdemont|title=Spanish judge jails eight members of deposed Catalan government|date=2 November 2017|work=The Guardian|location=Madrid|access-date=2 November 2017}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41840070|title=EU warrant sought for ex-Catalan leader|date=2017-11-02|work=BBC News|access-date=3 November 2017|language=en-GB}} The EAW demanding Puigdemont and his allies' arrest was officially issued to Belgium the next day, on 3 November, which Belgium said they would "study" before making any decisions.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41865121|title=Spain issues warrant for Catalan ex-leader|date=2017-11-03|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-11-04|language=en-GB}} The detention of the former Generalitat members led to increased protests in Catalonia, with thousands calling for "freedom" for whom they viewed as "political prisoners". Puigdemont declared from an undisclosed location in Belgium that he regarded the detentions as "an act that breaks with the basic principles of democracy".{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41854248|title=Catalan protest against Spain jail moves|date=2 November 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=3 November 2017|language=en-GB}} In contrast, a separate case against other Catalan lawmakers was adjourned by the [[Supreme Court of Spain|Supreme Court]] ({{lang-es|link=no|Tribunal Supremo}}) after all six of them, including Catalan parliament speaker Carme Forcadell, showed up to the summons.{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/11/02/europe/catalonia-spain-independence/index.html|title=Spanish court orders detention of 8 former Catalan ministers|date=2 November 2017|work=CNN|access-date=3 November 2017|language=en}} Puigdemont and the four other cabinet members turned themselves in to Belgian authorities on 5 November, awaiting a decision by the federal prosecutor on whether to hand them over to Spain or decline the warrant.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/nov/05/carles-puigdemont-turns-himself-in-to-belgian-police-catalonia|title=Carles Puigdemont turns himself in to Belgian police|last=Boffey|first=Daniel|date=5 November 2017|work=The Guardian|access-date=5 November 2017|language=en-GB}} They were released by the judge on the same day on conditions, such as they would not be able to leave the country without prior consent and would have to provide details to the police about their accommodation.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-41881961|title=Catalan ex-leader freed by Belgian judge|date=6 November 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=6 November 2016|language=en-GB}} On 5 December, six jailed members of the deposed government were freed on bail, while four others, including Oriol Junqueras, were required to remain imprisoned.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-42221657|title=Four Catalan separatists to stay in jail|date=2017-12-04|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-12-05|language=en-GB}} The next day, Spain withdrew the EAW against Puigdemont just over a month after issuing it to Belgian authorities.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-42237377|title=Catalan leaders' arrest warrants dropped|date=2017-12-05|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-12-05|language=en-GB}} ===Regional election and investiture=== {{Main|Catalan regional election, 2017}} [[File:Ben Emmerson (39437063524).jpg|thumb|Lawyers Jessica Jones, [[Ben Emmerson]] and Rachel Lindon take case of Catalonia's jailed politicians to the [[United Nations]], February 2018]] The 21 December regional election called by Rajoy resulted in pro-independence parties retaining a reduced majority with 70 seats overall, with Puigdemont's coalition, [[Junts per Catalunya]] (JxSí), performing above expectations.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-spain-politics-catalonia/catalan-separatists-win-vote-thwarting-rajoys-bid-to-solve-crisis-idUSKBN1EG13A|title=Spain's crisis re-ignited as Catalan separatists win vote|date=22 December 2017|publisher=|via=Reuters}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-42451100|title=Catalan ex-leader demands Spain talks|date=22 December 2017|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/dec/21/catalonia-election-set-to-give-victory-to-pro-independence-parties|title=Catalan pro-independence parties keep their majority in snap poll|first1=Sam|last1=Jones|first2=Stephen|last2=Burgen|date=22 December 2017|publisher=|via=www.theguardian.com}} With 36 seats, the main anti-independence party, [[Citizens (Spanish political party)|Citizens]], emerged as the largest in the Parliament,{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/ng-interactive/2017/dec/21/catalonia-election-full-results|title=Catalonia election: full results|publisher=|via=www.theguardian.com}} whereas Rajoy's [[People's Party (Spain)|People's Party]] was severely mauled after being reduced to 4.2% of the share and 4 out of 135 seats.{{cite web|url=http://catalanmonitor.com/2017/12/22/total-collapse-of-the-pp-in-catalonia-leaves-rajoy-exposed/|title=Total collapse of the PP in Catalonia leaves Rajoy exposed|first=Isaac|last=Meler|date=22 December 2017|publisher=|via=http://catalanmonitor.com}} [[Inés Arrimadas]], Citizens' leader in the region, announced she would not try to form a government on her own, instead waiting and see how negotiations between pro-independence parties evolved, due to them commanding a majority against her hypothetical candidacy.{{cite news |last=Piña |first=Raúl |date=27 December 2017 |title=Arrimadas no intentará la investidura para evitar el desgaste ante el PP |url=http://www.elmundo.es/cataluna/2017/12/27/5a42aec5468aeb1e1c8b45cb.html |language=Spanish |work=El Mundo |location=Madrid |access-date=6 January 2018}} As the candidate of the most-voted party within the pro-independence bloc, Puigdemont intended to be re-elected as President, but this was hampered by the fact he risked being arrested by Spanish authorities upon returning from Brussels. Further, pro-independence parties could only command 62 seats—six short of a majority—as in practice eight of their elected deputies were either in Brussels with Puigdemont or in [[preventive detention]].{{cite news |last=Romero |first=Juanma |date=3 January 2018 |title=El PSC aguarda el plan de Cs para la Mesa pero "facilitará" un presidente no 'indepe' |url=https://www.elconfidencial.com/espana/cataluna/elecciones-catalanas/2018-01-03/psc-propuesta-ciudadanos-mesa-facilitara-presidente-no-independentista_1500450/ |language=Spanish |work=El Confidencial |location= |access-date=6 January 2018}} After the Catalan parliament elected [[Roger Torrent]] as new speaker, Puigdemont was proposed as candidate for re-election as President of the Generalitat.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-42718192|title=Catalonia MPs elect separatist speaker as parliament reconvenes|date=17 January 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com|access-date=25 March 2018}} However, facing arrest on possible charges of rebellion, sedition and misuse of public funds, the Catalan parliament delayed Puigdemont's investiture after Constitutional Court ruled that he could not assume the presidency from abroad.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-42849055|title=Catalonia's Puigdemont cannot lead from abroad, court rules|date=27 January 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com|access-date=25 March 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jan/27/carles-puigdemont-must-return-to-catalonia-to-form-government|title=Puigdemont could return to Catalonia in attempt to retake office|date=27 January 2018|publisher=|via=www.theguardian.com|access-date=25 March 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jan/30/catalonia-parliament-postpones-carles-puigdemont-investiture-president|title=Catalan parliament delays vote on leader but backs Puigdemont|date=30 January 2018|publisher=|via=www.theguardian.com|access-date=25 March 2018}} With other pro-independence leaders assuring the pro-independence movement should outlive Puigdemont in order to end the political deadlock,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43146156|title=Jailed Catalan leader: We must unite to retake control|date=21 February 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com|access-date=25 March 2018}} the former Catalan president announced on 1 March he would step his claim aside in order to allow detained activist [[Jordi Sànchez i Picanyol|Jordi Sànchez]], from his [[Junts per Catalunya]] alliance, to become President instead.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43249664|title=Catalonia Spain: Fugitive Puigdemont abandons presidency|date=1 March 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com|access-date=25 March 2018}} However, as Spain's Supreme Court did not allow Sànchez to be freed from jail to attend his investiture ceremony,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43348994|title=Catalonia Spain: Judge refuses to release Jordi Sanchez for investiture|date=9 March 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com|access-date=25 March 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/mar/09/catalan-leader-jordi-sanchez-cannot-leave-jail-to-attend-debate-court-rules|title=Catalan leader cannot leave jail to attend debate, court rules|date=9 March 2018|publisher=|via=www.theguardian.com|access-date=25 March 2018}} Sànchez ended up giving up his candidacy on 21 March in favour of former Catalan government spokesman [[Jordi Turull]], who was also under investigation for his role in the referendum.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43483946|title=Catalonia crisis: Jailed activist Jordi Sanchez drops candidacy|date=21 March 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com|access-date=25 March 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/mar/22/catalan-secessionist-parties-propose-third-potential-leader-jordi-turull-courts|title=Catalan parties propose third potential leader in race against courts|date=22 March 2018|publisher=|via=www.theguardian.com|access-date=25 March 2018}} [[File:DC72027 (26645320167).jpg|thumb|250px|Protest march in Barcelona in support of [[Carles Puigdemont]] on 15 April 2018]] Turull was defeated in the first ballot of a hastily convened investiture session held on 22 March, with only his Junts per Catalunya alliance and ERC voting for him and the [[Popular Unity Candidacy]] abstaining, resulting in a 64–65 defeat. The next day and less than 24 hours before he was due to attend the second ballot, the Supreme Court announced that thirteen senior Catalan leaders—including Turull—would be charged with rebellion over their roles in the 2017 unilateral referendum and subsequent declaration of independence.{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/spain-charges-13-catalan-politicians-with-rebellion/a-43111974|title=Spain charges 13 Catalan politicians with rebellion|date=23 March 2018|publisher=Deutsche Welle|via=www.dw.com|access-date=25 March 2018}} Llarena sent five of them, including Turull and [[Carme Forcadell]], previous Catalan Parliament speaker, to preventive jail; being the others already in preventive jail or exile. In anticipation of this ruling and in order to avoid appearing in court, [[Marta Rovira]]—ERC's general secretary and deputy leader to jailed [[Oriol Junqueras]]—fled the country to Switzerland in "self-exile".{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/mar/23/jordi-turull-latest-candidate-catalan-presidency-appear-court-spain|title=Spanish court remands Catalan presidential candidate in custody|date=23 March 2018|publisher=The Guardian|via=www.theguardian.com|access-date=25 March 2018}} As a result, the Parliament speaker Roger Torrent cancelled Turull's second investiture ballot.{{cite news |last=Puente |first=Arturo |date=24 March 2018 |title=Torrent suspende la votación de investidura y realiza un pleno simbólico de apoyo a los encarcelados |url=https://www.eldiario.es/catalunya/politica/Torrent-votacion-legislatura-suspenso-declaracion_0_753474749.html |language=Spanish |work=eldiario.es |access-date=24 March 2018}} Thousands took the streets of dozens of Catalan cities to show discomfort with the decision of the court.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/av/world-europe-43523810/spain-catalonia-protesters-clash-with-police-after-court-ruling|title=Spain Catalonia: Protesters clash with police after court ruling|date=24 March 2018|publisher=BBC|via=www.bbc.com|access-date=25 March 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Spain-Thousands-Protest-in-Catalonia-After-Independence-Leaders-Held-20180324-0003.html |title=Spain: Thousands Protest in Catalonia After Independence Leaders Held |date=24 March 2018|publisher=Telesur|via=www.telesurtv.net|access-date=25 March 2018}} The [[European Arrest Warrant]] against Puigdemont was reactivated just as he was in a visit to Finland, but he had already left the country for Belgium before Finnish authorities received it.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43527492|title=Spain Catalonia: Ex-leader Puigdemont 'avoids Finnish arrest'|date=24 March 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com|access-date=25 March 2018}} On his way to Belgium on 25 March he was caught and detained in Germany while crossing the border from Denmark.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-43532217|title=Carles Puigdemont: Former Catalan president 'detained'|date=25 March 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com|access-date=25 March 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/mar/25/catalan-leader-carles-puigdemont-held-by-german-police|title=Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont held by German police|date=25 March 2018|publisher=|via=www.theguardian.com|access-date=25 March 2018}} On 4 April he was released on bail after the state court in Schleswig rejected extraditing him for rebellion, though he may still be extradited on corruption charges.{{cite news|title=Germany refuses to extradite Catalonia's Puigdemont on rebellion charges|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/carles-puigdemont-catalonia-germany-extradite-charges-rebellion-spain-arrest-a8290806.html|work=Independent|date=5 April 2018}}{{cite news|title=Puigdemont Cannot Be Extradited on Rebellion Charge, German Court Rules|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/05/world/europe/puigdemont-extradite-germany-spain.html|work=New York Times|date=5 April 2018}} ==Alleged international interference== {{See also|Reactions to the Catalan independence referendum, 2017}} {{Quote box|width=300px|align=right|quote=Many messages and operations that were seen via social networks come from Russian territory. And I use the correct expression: from Russian territory. That's not to say necessarily that we have determined that it is the Russian government. As such, we must act with extreme caution. We have to be clear on the origins. They are partly from Russian territory, partly from elsewhere, also outside the EU. We are determining this at the current time. |source=—Spanish Defence Minister [[María Dolores de Cospedal]]."[https://www.express.co.uk/news/world/879168/Spain-Catalonia-crisis-Russia-Mariano-Rajoy-Alfonso-Dastis-Carles-Puigdemont Spain blames RUSSIA for Catalonia crisis as Madrid accuses Moscow of DESTABILISING country ]". ''Express.co.uk.'' 13 November 2017."[https://euobserver.com/foreign/139843 Spain joins call for EU action on propaganda]". ''EUobserver.'' 13 November 2017.}} Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]] condemned Catalonia's independence referendum as "illegal"."[https://www.express.co.uk/news/world/860079/Catalonia-referendum-Vladimir-Putin-Russia-condemn-Spain-illegal 'Illegal' Putin condemns Catalonia referendum and will continue to treat Spain as one]". ''Express.co.uk.'' 28 September 2017. However, an analysis by the [[George Washington University School of Media and Public Affairs]] of over five million social media messages found that some [[Russia]]n media and accounts on social networks related to [[Venezuela]] allegedly collaborated on disseminating negative propaganda against the Spanish government days before and after the referendum. Russia's [[Russia today|''RT'']] and [[Sputnik (news agency)|''Sputnik'']] would use Venezuelan [[social bot]]s that would [[Bolivarian propaganda|typically promote the Bolivarian government in Venezuela]] to criticize the Spanish government and [[police violence]] against citizens in Catalonia. Social bots, anonymous accounts and official state media accounts shared 97% of the anti-Spain messages while only 3% of the messages were shared by real social media members. Leaders of the George Washington University study displayed concern about the findings, stating that "democratic systems have the obligation to investigate these signs and implement systematic methods of monitoring and responding to alleged disruptions of foreign agents" and that it appeared the authors of the propaganda are the same as the ones who allegedly interfered in the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 United States presidential election]] and [[Brexit]].{{cite news|last1=Alandete|first1=David|title=Russian network used Venezuelan accounts to deepen Catalan crisis|url=https://elpais.com/elpais/2017/11/11/inenglish/1510395422_468026.html|accessdate=11 November 2017|work=[[El País]]|date=11 November 2017|language=en}} The [[Spanish Ministry of Defence]] and the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation (Spain)|Spanish Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Cooperation]] later said it had confirmed that Russian actors and Venezuela had attempted to destabilize the nation and Europe by means of propaganda, though it would not confirm if the Russian government was directly involved and warned that similar misinformation actions may take place in future elections.{{cite news|last1=Cotovio|first1=Vasco|last2=Grinberg|first2=Emanuella|title=Spain: 'Misinformation' on Catalonia vote came from Russia|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/11/13/europe/catalonia-russia-connection-referendum/index.html|accessdate=15 November 2017|work=[[CNN]]|date=13 November 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Emmott|first1=Robin|title=Spain sees Russian interference in Catalonia separatist vote|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-spain-politics-catalonia-russia/spain-sees-russian-interference-in-catalonia-separatist-vote-idUSKBN1DD20Y|accessdate=15 November 2017|work=[[Reuters]]|date=13 November 2017}} [[NATO]] officials also made comments stating that Russia has been attempting to undermine Western governments through disinformation campaigns.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/the-latest-ex-catalan-president-to-lead-party-in-election/2017/11/15/7549e698-ca54-11e7-b506-8a10ed11ecf5_story.html|title=The Latest: Ex-Catalan president to lead party in election|publisher=The Washington Post|date=15 November 2017|accessdate=16 November 2017}} Members of Catalonia's separatist groups have denied allegations of foreign interference. [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Russia)|Russian Foreign Minister]] [[Sergey Lavrov]] said in response: "Probably they are arranging this kind of scandalous, sensational hysteria in order to distract the attention of their electorate from their inability to resolve their problems at home.""[https://www.rferl.org/a/russia-calls-spanish-leaders-accusations-may-have-meddled-catalonia-vote-hysteria/28856804.html Russia Calls Spain's Accusations It May Have Meddled In Catalonia Vote 'Hysteria']". ''[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]].'' November 16, 2017. Kremlin Spokesman [[Dmitry Peskov]] said on November 15: "The Spanish authorities, NATO, and the newspapers did not bring up a single worthwhile argument to back these claims. We consider these claims to be groundless, and more likely a deliberate or inadvertent continuation of the same hysteria that is now happening in the United States and a number of other countries." ==References== {{reflist}} {{Catalan nationalism}} {{Ongoing protests}} {{Portal bar|Catalan-speaking countries|Law|Politics|Spain}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2017-18 Spanish constitutional crisis}} [[Category:2017 in Catalonia]] [[Category:2017 in politics]] [[Category:2017 protests]] [[Category:2017 beginnings]] [[Category:2018 in Catalonia]] [[Category:2018 in politics]] [[Category:2018 protests|Spanish constitutional crisis]] [[Category:Catalan independence movement]] [[Category:Constitutional crises]] [[Category:Politics of Catalonia]] [[Category:Politics of Spain]] [[Category:Protests in Spain]] [[Category:September 2017 events in Spain]] [[Category:October 2017 events in Spain]] [[Category:November 2017 events in Spain]] [[Category:December 2017 events in Spain]] [[Category:January 2018 events in Spain]] [[Category:Ongoing conflicts]] [[Category:Ongoing protests]]

The '''Skystar 300''' is a [[surveillance blimp]]. It is an [[ISTAR|ISR]] system that provides surveillance capabilities accomplished by simple equipment, which requires minimal operating skills and maintenance procedures. The system is composed of the Aerostat Balloon, filled with [[Helium|helium gas]], dual sensor payload, control unit and the data link between the control unit and the balloon.
==Operators==
* {{ISR}} * {{MEX}} - The Mexican government has just signed a $22 million deal with Israeli company Aeronautics Defense Systems, Ltd. The contract will supply an unmanned spy plane and surveillance blimp to the [[Federal Preventive Police|Mexican Federal Police]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defenseworld.net/go/defensenews.jsp?subcatid=127&id=2789&h=Mexico+receive+Orbiter+UAV+from+Israel |title=Mexico to receive Orbiter UAV from Israel : Defense news |publisher=Defenseworld.net |date= |accessdate=2012-09-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222071556/http://www.defenseworld.net/go/defensenews.jsp?subcatid=127&id=2789&h=Mexico+receive+Orbiter+UAV+from+Israel |archivedate=2012-02-22 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSLG436688 |title=Mexico police buy Israeli air surveillance systems |publisher=Reuters |date=2009-02-16 |accessdate=2012-09-04}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} [[File:St James Town1.jpg|thumb|''Affordable housing'' or ''Low income housing'' at the [[St. James Town]] neighborhood in [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]], [[Canada]].]] '''Affordable housing''' is housing which is deemed affordable to those with a [[median household income]]{{cite book |title=Analysis of Urban Growth and Sprawl from Remote Sensing Data |author=Bhatta, Basudeb |publisher=Springer |series=Advances in Geographic Information Science |isbn= 978-3-642-05298-9 |date=15 April 2010 |page=23 }} as rated by the [[Government|national government]] or a [[local government]] by a recognized [[housing affordability index]]. Most of the literature on affordable housing refers to mortgages and number of forms that exist along a continuum – from emergency shelters, to transitional housing, to non-market rental (also known as social or [[subsidized housing]]), to formal and informal rental, indigenous housing, and ending with affordable home ownership.{{cite web | url=http://www.calgary.ca/CSPS/CNS/Documents/homelessness/ff-01_definition_affordable_housing.pdf | title=Definition Affordable Housing | format=PDF}}[http://www.cnhed.org/shared/layouts/singleblock.jsp?_event=view&_id=120130_U127242__194346 CNHED] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204163809/http://www.cnhed.org/shared/layouts/singleblock.jsp?_event=view&_id=120130_U127242__194346 |date=4 February 2012 }}{{cite web | url=http://www.qahc.asn.au/images2/website/affordabilitychart.pdf | title=Queensland Affordable Housing Consortium [QAHC], Australia | format=PDF | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426044456/http://www.qahc.asn.au/images2/website/affordabilitychart.pdf | archivedate=26 April 2012 | df=dmy-all }}{{cite journal |url =
